column2: NOW, saith the tale, after Sir Gawaine departed, he rode many journeys, both toward and froward.
column3: NOW, saith the tale, after Sir Gawaine departed, he rode many journeys, both toward and froward.

column2: And at the last he came to the abbey where Sir Galahad had the white shield, and there Sir Gawaine learned the way to sewe after Sir Galahad; and so he rode to the abbey where Melias lay sick, and there Sir Melias told Sir Gawaine of the marvellous adventures that Sir Galahad did.
column3: And at the last he came to the abbey where Sir Galahad had the white shield, and there Sir Gawaine learned the way to sewe after Sir Galahad; and so he rode to the abbey where Melias lay sick, and there Sir Melias told Sir Gawaine of the marvellous adventures that Sir Galahad did.

column2: Certes, said Sir Gawaine, I am not happy that I took not the way that he went, for an I may meet with him I will not depart from him lightly, for all marvellous adventures Sir Galahad enchieveth.
column3: Certes, said Sir Gawaine, I am not happy that I took not the way that he went, for an I may meet with him I will not depart from him lightly, for all marvellous adventures Sir Galahad enchieveth.

column2: Sir, said one of the monks, he will not of your fellowship. Why? said Sir Gawaine.
column3: Sir, said one of the monks, he will not of your fellowship. Why? said Sir Gawaine.

column2: Sir, said he, for ye be wicked and sinful, and he is full blessed.
column3: Sir, said he, for ye be wicked and sinful, and he is full blessed.

column2: Right as they thus stood talking there came in riding Sir Gareth.
column3: Right as they thus stood talking there came in riding Sir Gareth.

column2: And then they made joy either of other.
column3: And then they made joy either of other.

column2: And on the morn they heard mass, and so departed.
column3: And on the morn they heard mass, and so departed.

column2: And by the way they met with Sir Uwaine les Avoutres, and there Sir Uwaine told Sir Gawaine how he had met with none adventure sith he departed from the court.
column3: And by the way they met with Sir Uwaine les Avoutres, and there Sir Uwaine told Sir Gawaine how he had met with none adventure sith he departed from the court.

column2: Nor we, said Sir Gawaine.
column3: Nor we, said Sir Gawaine.

column2: And either promised other of the three knights not to depart while they were in that quest, but if fortune caused it.
column3: And either promised other of the three knights not to depart while they were in that quest, but if fortune caused it.

column2: So they departed and rode by fortune till that they came by the Castle of Maidens; and there the seven brethren espied the three knights, and said: Sithen, we be flemed by one knight from this castle, we shall destroy all the knights of King Arthur's that we may overcome, for the love of Sir Galahad.
column3: So they departed and rode by fortune till that they came by the Castle of Maidens; and there the seven brethren espied the three knights, and said: Sithen, we be flemed by one knight from this castle, we shall destroy all the knights of King Arthur's that we may overcome, for the love of Sir Galahad.

column2: And therewith the seven knights set upon the three knights, and by fortune Sir Gawaine slew one of the brethren, and each one of his fellows slew another, and so slew the remnant.
column3: And therewith the seven knights set upon the three knights, and by fortune Sir Gawaine slew one of the brethren, and each one of his fellows slew another, and so slew the remnant.

column2: And then they took the way under the castle, and there they lost the way that Sir Galahad rode, and there everych of them departed from other; and Sir Gawaine rode till he came to an hermitage, and there he found the good man saying his evensong of Our Lady; and there Sir Gawaine asked harbour for charity, and the good man granted it him gladly.
column3: And then they took the way under the castle, and there they lost the way that Sir Galahad rode, and there everych of them departed from other; and Sir Gawaine rode till he came to an hermitage, and there he found the good man saying his evensong of Our Lady; and there Sir Gawaine asked harbour for charity, and the good man granted it him gladly.

column2: Then the good man asked him what he was.
column3: Then the good man asked him what he was.

column2: Sir, he said, I am a knight of King Arthur's that am in the quest of the Sangreal, and my name is Sir Gawaine.
column3: Sir, he said, I am a knight of King Arthur's that am in the quest of the Sangreal, and my name is Sir Gawaine.

column2: Sir, said the good man, I would wit how it standeth betwixt God and you.
column3: Sir, said the good man, I would wit how it standeth betwixt God and you.

column2: Sir, said Sir Gawaine, I will with a good will shew you my life if it please you; and there he told the hermit how a monk of an abbey called me wicked knight.
column3: Sir, said Sir Gawaine, I will with a good will shew you my life if it please you; and there he told the hermit how a monk of an abbey called me wicked knight.

column2: He might well say it, said the hermit, for when ye were first made knight ye should have taken you to knightly deeds and virtuous living, and ye have done the contrary, for ye have lived mischievously many winters; and Sir Galahad is a maid and sinned never, and that is the cause he shall enchieve where he goeth that ye nor none such shall not attain, nor none in your fellowship, for ye have used the most untruest life that ever I heard knight live.
column3: He might well say it, said the hermit, for when ye were first made knight ye should have taken you to knightly deeds and virtuous living, and ye have done the contrary, for ye have lived mischievously many winters; and Sir Galahad is a maid and sinned never, and that is the cause he shall enchieve where he goeth that ye nor none such shall not attain, nor none in your fellowship, for ye have used the most untruest life that ever I heard knight live.

column2: For certes had ye not been so wicked as ye are, never had the seven brethren been slain by you and your two fellows.
column3: For certes had ye not been so wicked as ye are, never had the seven brethren been slain by you and your two fellows.

column2: For Sir Galahad himself alone beat them all seven the day to-fore, but his living is such he shall slay no man lightly. Also I may say you the Castle of Maidens betokeneth the good souls that were in prison afore the Incarnation of Jesu Christ.
column3: For Sir Galahad himself alone beat them all seven the day to fore, but his living is such he shall slay no man lightly. Also I may say you the Castle of Maidens betokeneth the good souls that were in prison afore the Incarnation of Jesu Christ.

column2: And the seven knights betoken the seven deadly sins that reigned that time in the world; and I may liken the good Galahad unto the son of the High Father, that lighted within a maid, and bought all the souls out of thrall, so did Sir Galahad deliver all the maidens out of the woful castle.
column3: And the seven knights betoken the seven deadly sins that reigned that time in the world; and I may liken the good Galahad unto the son of the High Father, that lighted within a maid, and bought all the souls out of thrall, so did Sir Galahad deliver all the maidens out of the woful castle.

column2: Now, Sir Gawaine, said the good man, thou must do penance for thy sin. Sir, what penance shall I do?
column3: Now, Sir Gawaine, said the good man, thou must do penance for thy sin. Sir, what penance shall I do?

column2: Such as I will give, said the good man. Nay, said Sir Gawaine, I may do no penance; for we knights adventurous oft suffer great woe and pain.
column3: Such as I will give, said the good man. Nay, said Sir Gawaine, I may do no penance; for we knights adventurous oft suffer great woe and pain.

column2: Well, said the good man, and then he held his peace.
column3: Well, said the good man, and then he held his peace.

column2: And on the morn Sir Gawaine departed from the hermit, and betaught him unto God.
column3: And on the morn Sir Gawaine departed from the hermit, and betaught him unto God.

column2: And by adventure he met with Sir Aglovale and Sir Griflet, two knights of the Table Round.
column3: And by adventure he met with Sir Aglovale and Sir Griflet, two knights of the Table Round.

column2: And they two rode four days without finding of any adventure, and at the fifth day they departed. And everych held as fell them by adventure.
column3: And they two rode four days without finding of any adventure, and at the fifth day they departed. And everych held as fell them by adventure.

column2: Here leaveth the tale of Sir Gawaine and his fellows, and speak we of Sir Galahad.
column3: Here leaveth the tale of Sir Gawaine and his fellows, and speak we of Sir Galahad.

column2: CHAPTER XVII.
column3: CHAPTER seventeen.

column2: How Sir Galahad met with Sir Launcelot and Sir Percivale, and smote them down, and departed from them.
column3: How Sir Galahad met with Sir Launcelot and Sir Percivale, and smote them down, and departed from them.

column2: So when Sir Galahad was departed from the Castle of Maidens he rode till he came to a waste forest, and there he met with Sir Launcelot and Sir Percivale, but they knew him not, for he was new disguised.
column3: So when Sir Galahad was departed from the Castle of Maidens he rode till he came to a waste forest, and there he met with Sir Launcelot and Sir Percivale, but they knew him not, for he was new disguised.

column2: Right so Sir Launcelot, his father, dressed his spear and brake it upon Sir Galahad, and Galahad smote him so again that he smote down horse and man.
column3: Right so Sir Launcelot, his father, dressed his spear and brake it upon Sir Galahad, and Galahad smote him so again that he smote down horse and man.

column2: And then he drew his sword, and dressed him unto Sir Percivale, and smote him so on the helm, that it rove to the coif of steel; and had not the sword swerved Sir Percivale had been slain, and with the stroke he fell out of his saddle.
column3: And then he drew his sword, and dressed him unto Sir Percivale, and smote him so on the helm, that it rove to the coif of steel; and had not the sword swerved Sir Percivale had been slain, and with the stroke he fell out of his saddle.

column2: This jousts was done to-fore the hermitage where a recluse dwelled.
column3: This jousts was done to fore the hermitage where a recluse dwelled.

column2: And when she saw Sir Galahad ride, she said: God be with thee, best knight of the world.
column3: And when she saw Sir Galahad ride, she said: God be with thee, best knight of the world.

column2: Ah certes, said she, all aloud that Launcelot and Percivale might hear it: An yonder two knights had known thee as well as I do they would not have encountered with thee.
column3: Ah certes, said she, all aloud that Launcelot and Percivale might hear it: An yonder two knights had known thee as well as I do they would not have encountered with thee.

column2: Then Sir Galahad heard her say so he was adread to be known: therewith he smote his horse with his spurs and rode a great pace froward them.
column3: Then Sir Galahad heard her say so he was adread to be known: therewith he smote his horse with his spurs and rode a great pace froward them.

column2: Then perceived they both that he was Galahad; and up they gat on their horses, and rode fast after him, but in a while he was out of their sight.
column3: Then perceived they both that he was Galahad; and up they gat on their horses, and rode fast after him, but in a while he was out of their sight.

column2: And then they turned again with heavy cheer.
column3: And then they turned again with heavy cheer.

column2: Let us spere some tidings, said Percivale, at yonder recluse.
column3: Let us spere some tidings, said Percivale, at yonder recluse.

column2: Do as ye list, said Sir Launcelot.
column3: Do as ye list, said Sir Launcelot.

column2: When Sir Percivale came to the recluse she knew him well enough, and Sir Launcelot both.
column3: When Sir Percivale came to the recluse she knew him well enough, and Sir Launcelot both.

column2: But Sir Launcelot rode overthwart and endlong in a wild forest, and held no path but as wild adventure led him.
column3: But Sir Launcelot rode overthwart and endlong in a wild forest, and held no path but as wild adventure led him.

column2: And at the last he came to a stony cross which departed two ways in waste land; and by the cross was a stone that was of marble, but it was so dark that Sir Launcelot might not wit what it was.
column3: And at the last he came to a stony cross which departed two ways in waste land; and by the cross was a stone that was of marble, but it was so dark that Sir Launcelot might not wit what it was.

column2: Then Sir Launcelot looked by him, and saw an old chapel, and there he weened to have found people; and Sir Launcelot tied his horse till a tree, and there he did off his shield and hung it upon a tree, and then went to the chapel door, and found it waste and broken.
column3: Then Sir Launcelot looked by him, and saw an old chapel, and there he weened to have found people; and Sir Launcelot tied his horse till a tree, and there he did off his shield and hung it upon a tree, and then went to the chapel door, and found it waste and broken.

column2: And within he found a fair altar, full richly arrayed with cloth of clean silk, and there stood a fair clean candlestick, which bare six great candles, and the candlestick was of silver.
column3: And within he found a fair altar, full richly arrayed with cloth of clean silk, and there stood a fair clean candlestick, which bare six great candles, and the candlestick was of silver.

column2: And when Sir Launcelot saw this light he had great will for to enter into the chapel, but he could find no place where he might enter; then was he passing heavy and dismayed.
column3: And when Sir Launcelot saw this light he had great will for to enter into the chapel, but he could find no place where he might enter; then was he passing heavy and dismayed.

column2: Then he returned and came to his horse and did off his saddle and bridle, and let him pasture, and unlaced his helm, and ungirt his sword, and laid him down to sleep upon his shield to-fore the cross.
column3: Then he returned and came to his horse and did off his saddle and bridle, and let him pasture, and unlaced his helm, and ungirt his sword, and laid him down to sleep upon his shield to fore the cross.

column2: CHAPTER XVIII.
column3: CHAPTER eighteen.

column2: How Sir Launcelot, half sleeping and half waking, saw a sick man borne in a litter, and how he was healed with the Sangreal.
column3: How Sir Launcelot, half sleeping and half waking, saw a sick man borne in a litter, and how he was healed with the Sangreal.

column2: AND so he fell asleep; and half waking and sleeping he saw come by him two palfreys all fair and white, the which bare a litter, therein lying a sick knight.
column3: AND so he fell asleep; and half waking and sleeping he saw come by him two palfreys all fair and white, the which bare a litter, therein lying a sick knight.

column2: And when he was nigh the cross he there abode still.
column3: And when he was nigh the cross he there abode still.

column2: All this Sir Launcelot saw and beheld, for he slept not verily; and he heard him say: O sweet Lord, when shall this sorrow leave me? and when shall the holy vessel come by me, wherethrough I shall be blessed?
column3: All this Sir Launcelot saw and beheld, for he slept not verily; and he heard him say: O sweet Lord, when shall this sorrow leave me? and when shall the holy vessel come by me, wherethrough I shall be blessed?

column2: For I have endured thus long, for little trespass.
column3: For I have endured thus long, for little trespass.

column2: A full great while complained the knight thus, and always Sir Launcelot heard it.
column3: A full great while complained the knight thus, and always Sir Launcelot heard it.

column2: With that Sir Launcelot saw the candlestick with the six tapers come before the cross, and he saw nobody that brought it.
column3: With that Sir Launcelot saw the candlestick with the six tapers come before the cross, and he saw nobody that brought it.

column2: Also there came a table of silver, and the holy vessel of the Sangreal, which Launcelot had seen aforetime in King Pescheour's house.
column3: Also there came a table of silver, and the holy vessel of the Sangreal, which Launcelot had seen aforetime in King Pescheour's house.

column2: And therewith the sick knight set him up, and held up both his hands, and said: Fair sweet Lord, which is here within this holy vessel; take heed unto me that I may be whole of this malady. And therewith on his hands and on his knees he went so nigh that he touched the holy vessel and kissed it, and anon he was whole; and then he said: Lord God, I thank thee, for I am healed of this sickness.
column3: And therewith the sick knight set him up, and held up both his hands, and said: Fair sweet Lord, which is here within this holy vessel; take heed unto me that I may be whole of this malady. And therewith on his hands and on his knees he went so nigh that he touched the holy vessel and kissed it, and anon he was whole; and then he said: Lord God, I thank thee, for I am healed of this sickness.

column2: So when the holy vessel had been there a great while it went unto the chapel with the chandelier and the light, so that Launcelot wist not where it was become; for he was overtaken with sin that he had no power to rise again the holy vessel; wherefore after that many men said of him shame, but he took repentance after that.
column3: So when the holy vessel had been there a great while it went unto the chapel with the chandelier and the light, so that Launcelot wist not where it was become; for he was overtaken with sin that he had no power to rise again the holy vessel; wherefore after that many men said of him shame, but he took repentance after that.

column2: Then the sick knight dressed him up and kissed the cross; anon his squire brought him his arms, and asked his lord how he did.
column3: Then the sick knight dressed him up and kissed the cross; anon his squire brought him his arms, and asked his lord how he did.

column2: Certes, said he, I thank God right well, through the holy vessel I am healed.
column3: Certes, said he, I thank God right well, through the holy vessel I am healed.

column2: But I have marvel of this sleeping knight that had no power to awake when this holy vessel was brought hither.
column3: But I have marvel of this sleeping knight that had no power to awake when this holy vessel was brought hither.

column2: I dare right well say, said the squire, that he dwelleth in some deadly sin whereof he was never confessed.
column3: I dare right well say, said the squire, that he dwelleth in some deadly sin whereof he was never confessed.

column2: By my faith, said the knight, whatsomever he be he is unhappy, for as I deem he is of the fellowship of the Round Table, the which is entered into the quest of the Sangreal. Sir, said the squire, here I have brought you all your arms save your helm and your sword, and therefore by mine assent now may ye take this knight's helm and his sword: and so he did.
column3: By my faith, said the knight, whatsomever he be he is unhappy, for as I deem he is of the fellowship of the Round Table, the which is entered into the quest of the Sangreal. Sir, said the squire, here I have brought you all your arms save your helm and your sword, and therefore by mine assent now may ye take this knight's helm and his sword: and so he did.

column2: And when he was clean armed he took Sir Launcelot's horse, for he was better than his; and so departed they from the cross.
column3: And when he was clean armed he took Sir Launcelot's horse, for he was better than his; and so departed they from the cross.

column2: CHAPTER XIX.
column3: CHAPTER nineteen.

column2: How a voice spake to Sir Launcelot, and how he found his horse and his helm borne away, and after went afoot.
column3: How a voice spake to Sir Launcelot, and how he found his horse and his helm borne away, and after went afoot.

column2: THEN anon Sir Launcelot waked, and set him up, and bethought him what he had seen there, and whether it were dreams or not.
column3: THEN anon Sir Launcelot waked, and set him up, and bethought him what he had seen there, and whether it were dreams or not.

column2: Right so heard he a voice that said: Sir Launcelot, more harder than is the stone, and more bitter than is the wood, and more naked and barer than is the leaf of the fig tree; therefore go thou from hence, and withdraw thee from this holy place.
column3: Right so heard he a voice that said: Sir Launcelot, more harder than is the stone, and more bitter than is the wood, and more naked and barer than is the leaf of the fig tree; therefore go thou from hence, and withdraw thee from this holy place.

column2: And when Sir Launcelot heard this he was passing heavy and wist not what to do, and so departed sore weeping, and cursed the time that he was born.
column3: And when Sir Launcelot heard this he was passing heavy and wist not what to do, and so departed sore weeping, and cursed the time that he was born.

column2: For then he deemed never to have had worship more.
column3: For then he deemed never to have had worship more.

column2: For those words went to his heart, till that he knew wherefore he was called so.
column3: For those words went to his heart, till that he knew wherefore he was called so.

column2: Then Sir Launcelot went to the cross and found his helm, his sword, and his horse taken away.
column3: Then Sir Launcelot went to the cross and found his helm, his sword, and his horse taken away.

column2: And then he called himself a very wretch, and most unhappy of all knights; and there he said: My sin and my wickedness have brought me unto great dishonour.
column3: And then he called himself a very wretch, and most unhappy of all knights; and there he said: My sin and my wickedness have brought me unto great dishonour.

column2: For when I sought worldly adventures for worldly desires, I ever enchieved them and had the better in every place, and never was I discomfit in no quarrel, were it right or wrong.
column3: For when I sought worldly adventures for worldly desires, I ever enchieved them and had the better in every place, and never was I discomfit in no quarrel, were it right or wrong.

column2: And now I take upon me the adventures of holy things, and now I see and understand that mine old sin hindereth me and shameth me, so that I had no power to stir nor speak when the holy blood appeared afore me.
column3: And now I take upon me the adventures of holy things, and now I see and understand that mine old sin hindereth me and shameth me, so that I had no power to stir nor speak when the holy blood appeared afore me.

column2: So thus he sorrowed till it was day, and heard the fowls sing: then somewhat he was comforted.
column3: So thus he sorrowed till it was day, and heard the fowls sing: then somewhat he was comforted.

column2: But when Sir Launcelot missed his horse and his harness then he wist well God was displeased with him.
column3: But when Sir Launcelot missed his horse and his harness then he wist well God was displeased with him.

column2: Then he departed from the cross on foot into a forest; and so by prime he came to an high hill, and found an hermitage and a hermit therein which was going unto mass.
column3: Then he departed from the cross on foot into a forest; and so by prime he came to an high hill, and found an hermitage and a hermit therein which was going unto mass.

column2: And then Launcelot kneeled down and cried on Our Lord mercy for his wicked works.
column3: And then Launcelot kneeled down and cried on Our Lord mercy for his wicked works.

column2: So when mass was done Launcelot called him, and prayed him for charity for to hear his life.
column3: So when mass was done Launcelot called him, and prayed him for charity for to hear his life.

column2: With a good will, said the good man.
column3: With a good will, said the good man.

column2: Sir, said he, be ye of King Arthur's court and of the fellowship of the Round Table?
column3: Sir, said he, be ye of King Arthur's court and of the fellowship of the Round Table?

column2: Yea forsooth, and my name is Sir Launcelot du Lake that hath been right well said of, and now my good fortune is changed, for I am the most wretch of the world.
column3: Yea forsooth, and my name is Sir Launcelot du Lake that hath been right well said of, and now my good fortune is changed, for I am the most wretch of the world.

column2: The hermit beheld him and had marvel how he was so abashed.
column3: The hermit beheld him and had marvel how he was so abashed.

column2: Sir, said the hermit, ye ought to thank God more than any knight living, for He hath caused you to have more worldly worship than any knight that now liveth.
column3: Sir, said the hermit, ye ought to thank God more than any knight living, for He hath caused you to have more worldly worship than any knight that now liveth.

column2: And for your presumption to take upon you in deadly sin for to be in His presence, where His flesh and His blood was, that caused you ye might not see it with worldly eyes; for He will not appear where such sinners be, but if it be unto their great hurt and unto their great shame; and there is no knight living now that ought to give God so great thank as ye, for He hath given you beauty, seemliness, and great strength above all other knights; and therefore ye are the more beholding unto God than any other man, to love Him and dread Him, for your strength and manhood will little avail you an God be against you.
column3: And for your presumption to take upon you in deadly sin for to be in His presence, where His flesh and His blood was, that caused you ye might not see it with worldly eyes; for He will not appear where such sinners be, but if it be unto their great hurt and unto their great shame; and there is no knight living now that ought to give God so great thank as ye, for He hath given you beauty, seemliness, and great strength above all other knights; and therefore ye are the more beholding unto God than any other man, to love Him and dread Him, for your strength and manhood will little avail you an God be against you.

column2: CHAPTER XX.
column3: CHAPTER twenty.

column2: How Sir Launcelot was shriven, and what sorrow he made and of the good ensamples which were shewed him.
column3: How Sir Launcelot was shriven, and what sorrow he made and of the good ensamples which were shewed him.

column2: THEN Sir Launcelot wept with heavy cheer, and said: Now I know well ye say me sooth.
column3: THEN Sir Launcelot wept with heavy cheer, and said: Now I know well ye say me sooth.

column2: Sir, said the good man, hide none old sin from me.
column3: Sir, said the good man, hide none old sin from me.

column2: Truly, said Sir Launcelot, that were me full loath to discover.
column3: Truly, said Sir Launcelot, that were me full loath to discover.

column2: For this fourteen year I never discovered one thing that I have used, and that may I now wite my shame and my disadventure.
column3: For this fourteen year I never discovered one thing that I have used, and that may I now wite my shame and my disadventure.

column2: And then he told there that good man all his life.
column3: And then he told there that good man all his life.

column2: And how he had loved a queen unmeasurably and out of measure long.
column3: And how he had loved a queen unmeasurably and out of measure long.

column2: And all my great deeds of arms that I have done, I did for the most part for the queen's sake, and for her sake would I do battle were it right or wrong, and never did I battle all only for God's sake, but for to win worship and to cause me to be the better beloved and little or nought I thanked God of it.
column3: And all my great deeds of arms that I have done, I did for the most part for the queen's sake, and for her sake would I do battle were it right or wrong, and never did I battle all only for God's sake, but for to win worship and to cause me to be the better beloved and little or nought I thanked God of it.

column2: Then Sir Launcelot said: I pray you counsel me.
column3: Then Sir Launcelot said: I pray you counsel me.

column2: I will counsel you, said the hermit, if ye will ensure me that ye will never come in that queen's fellowship as much as ye may forbear.
column3: I will counsel you, said the hermit, if ye will ensure me that ye will never come in that queen's fellowship as much as ye may forbear.

column2: And then Sir Launcelot promised him he nold, by the faith of his body.
column3: And then Sir Launcelot promised him he nold, by the faith of his body.

column2: Look that your heart and your mouth accord, said the good man, and I shall ensure you ye shall have more worship than ever ye had.
column3: Look that your heart and your mouth accord, said the good man, and I shall ensure you ye shall have more worship than ever ye had.

column2: Holy father, said Sir Launcelot, I marvel of the voice that said to me marvellous words, as ye have heard to-forehand.
column3: Holy father, said Sir Launcelot, I marvel of the voice that said to me marvellous words, as ye have heard to forehand.

column2: Have ye no marvel, said the good man thereof, for it seemeth well God loveth you; for men may understand a stone is hard of kind, and namely one more than another; and that is to understand by thee, Sir Launcelot, for thou wilt not leave thy sin for no goodness that God hath sent thee; therefore thou art more than any stone, and never wouldst thou be made nesh nor by water nor by fire, and that is the heat of the Holy Ghost may not enter in thee.
column3: Have ye no marvel, said the good man thereof, for it seemeth well God loveth you; for men may understand a stone is hard of kind, and namely one more than another; and that is to understand by thee, Sir Launcelot, for thou wilt not leave thy sin for no goodness that God hath sent thee; therefore thou art more than any stone, and never wouldst thou be made nesh nor by water nor by fire, and that is the heat of the Holy Ghost may not enter in thee.

column2: Now take heed, in all the world men shall not find one knight to whom Our Lord hath given so much of grace as He hath given you, for He hath given you fairness with seemliness, He hath given thee wit, discretion to know good from evil, He hath given thee prowess and hardiness, and given thee to work so largely that thou hast had at all days the better wheresomever thou came; and now Our Lord will suffer thee no longer, but that thou shalt know Him whether thou wilt or nylt. And why the voice called thee bitterer than wood, for where overmuch sin dwelleth, there may be but little sweetness, wherefore thou art likened to an old rotten tree.
column3: Now take heed, in all the world men shall not find one knight to whom Our Lord hath given so much of grace as He hath given you, for He hath given you fairness with seemliness, He hath given thee wit, discretion to know good from evil, He hath given thee prowess and hardiness, and given thee to work so largely that thou hast had at all days the better wheresomever thou came; and now Our Lord will suffer thee no longer, but that thou shalt know Him whether thou wilt or n y l t. And why the voice called thee bitterer than wood, for where overmuch sin dwelleth, there may be but little sweetness, wherefore thou art likened to an old rotten tree.

column2: Now have I shewed thee why thou art harder than the stone and bitterer than the tree.
column3: Now have I shewed thee why thou art harder than the stone and bitterer than the tree.

column2: Now shall I shew thee why thou art more naked and barer than the fig tree.
column3: Now shall I shew thee why thou art more naked and barer than the fig tree.

column2: It befell that Our Lord on Palm Sunday preached in Jerusalem, and there He found in the people that all hardness was harboured in them, and there He found in all the town not one that would harbour him.
column3: It befell that Our Lord on Palm Sunday preached in Jerusalem, and there He found in the people that all hardness was harboured in them, and there He found in all the town not one that would harbour him.

column2: And then He went without the town, and found in midst of the way a fig tree, the which was right fair and well garnished of leaves, but fruit had it none.
column3: And then He went without the town, and found in midst of the way a fig tree, the which was right fair and well garnished of leaves, but fruit had it none.

column2: Then Our Lord cursed the tree that bare no fruit; that betokeneth the fig tree unto Jerusalem, that had leaves and no fruit.
column3: Then Our Lord cursed the tree that bare no fruit; that betokeneth the fig tree unto Jerusalem, that had leaves and no fruit.

column2: So thou, Sir Launcelot, when the Holy Grail was brought afore thee, He found in thee no fruit, nor good thought nor good will, and defouled with lechery.
column3: So thou, Sir Launcelot, when the Holy Grail was brought afore thee, He found in thee no fruit, nor good thought nor good will, and defouled with lechery.

column2: Certes, said Sir Launcelot, all that you have said is true, and from henceforward I cast me, by the grace of God, never to be so wicked as I have been, but as to follow knighthood and to do feats of arms.
column3: Certes, said Sir Launcelot, all that you have said is true, and from henceforward I cast me, by the grace of God, never to be so wicked as I have been, but as to follow knighthood and to do feats of arms.

column2: Then the good man enjoined Sir Launcelot such penance as he might do and to sewe knighthood, and so assoiled him, and prayed Sir Launcelot to abide with him all that day.
column3: Then the good man enjoined Sir Launcelot such penance as he might do and to sewe knighthood, and so assoiled him, and prayed Sir Launcelot to abide with him all that day.

column2: I will well, said Sir Launcelot, for I have neither helm, nor horse, nor sword.
column3: I will well, said Sir Launcelot, for I have neither helm, nor horse, nor sword.

column2: As for that, said the good man, I shall help you or to-morn at even of an horse, and all that longed unto you.
column3: As for that, said the good man, I shall help you or to morn at even of an horse, and all that longed unto you.

column2: And then Sir Launcelot repented him greatly.
column3: And then Sir Launcelot repented him greatly.
